segments.text: This is June the 14th, 1988. And I've just decided I'm going to put my obituary on tape. And it will save those left behind the trouble of figuring out all my brothers and sisters.
And they can use this as a guide and it will probably be about what they want to put in the obituary.
So I'll start out with Achen Lyndon Hillary, 86 years of age, born in Mars, Iowa, immigrated with his family to Canada in 1907.
Pre-deceased by his parents.
One son.
Two brothers and three sisters. Leaves to mourn.
His loving wife, Phyllis. Two sons, Norman and Daniel. Norman and Linda, in brackets, and Daniel.
Three daughters, Linda and John, in brackets.
Verlin Feist and Blaise, in brackets.
And Jane Waugh, Joe, in brackets.
And eight grandchildren.
Prayers in the evening of so-and-so.
A funeral mass at 7.30, 13.30 in the evening.
Cremation and private burial.
Arrangements by Spears, whichever.
And I'll play this back and I'll see how it sounds.
I forgot to add, after naming the children, eight grandchildren.
Yes, I found I had room enough to put it in after Jane and Joel Waugh were mentioned.
So that's taken care of.
The end.
Now I'm going to add a little more about my history,
which possibly many of my family don't even know.
My business life.
After working at home on the farm until I was 24 years old,
when I left the farm and started working in the electrical field in Iowa,
I worked for, in two years I worked for the Iowa Electric,
the Northern Light and Power in South Dakota,
the Montana-Dakota Power Company in North Dakota,
and then went to the Dominion Electric Power Company in Estevan, Saskatchewan.
And the next electric company I worked for was the Tompkins Electric in Saskatchewan,
where I operated the power plant.
Took care of the business
for two and a half years before it was sold out to the Dominion Electric.
And then I will add that while being a foreman from the time,
from two years after the time I started, I was always in charge of men.
And my first venture into business was to become the president
and general manager of Tompkins Electric,
which was just a small electric plant, diesel plant.
And from there I went back to work for the Dominion Electric Power
and started contracting on my own in 1945.
And I might mention that I was the president of Tompkins Electric,
the president of Achen Minerals,
the founding president of RAL Minerals Limited,
the founding president of the Central Line Contractors Association,
a charter member of the Kinsmen of Canada in the Estevan branch,
a lifetime member of the EPOE, Elks Lodge of Canada,
a life member of the Knights of Columbus, third degree,
and a 33-year member of the Fourth Green Knights Father Huguenot Assembly.
A member of the Regina Chamber of Commerce for 22 years.
Became a journeyman electrician in 1934
and still carry a journeyman certificate at the age of 86,
though I never use it.
I have been on the payroll of Achen Construction 1965 Limited
since the inception of the company 21 years ago.
They still pay me a standby pittance
on account of my electrical journeyman's license,
which sometimes is necessary.
They have a journeyman on certain types of work.
And that's just a quick resume of some of the things that I did in my lifetime.
I just got thinking about that the other day,
and I thought, hey, not many guys have been president of so many companies.
They weren't very big ones, but they still needed looking after.
I might add, and I forgot to add,
I was the founding president of Achen Construction Company in 1953
and remained as president until the company was sold in 1965
to Achen Construction 1965 Limited,
at which time I went into semi-retirement.
End.
Employees.
And it is still operating under my name,
although since I made this tape,
the company has been sold,
sold all shares of the company.
And the name stayed with it.
The men that are running it now still use the name,
Achen Construction 1965 Limited.
I also, in replaying this now,
noticed that I hadn't mentioned
Survived by Sister Hillary.
And of course, she being two and a half years older than I,
it's always assumed that she's going to die ahead of me.
But that's not for sure.
I just outlined all this.
I doubt if any of my children know
of all the different things that I was involved in
in my lifetime.
None of them very big.
None of them very important.
But they all served a purpose.
There's a look so bashful in your eyes
That convinces me not to rise
Beside you
When you smile
You don't have any
You've got the holes in it.
It's not a sprinkling hole, Jay.
Well, that's a sprinkler.
That sprays up when you turn it.
The pressure's going to shoot up in the air
five, six feet and spread out all over.
And it wouldn't do that last night?
No, there wasn't enough pressure.
See, that's why they say
you ought to just put down the pressure
and you can just let it flow.
Oh, I see.
I had a bank operation.
I took this baby on Monday.
I said, I'm going to just go out on my own.
So I went on a new Santa Fe,
St. Catharines Street.
And I ran and got it done on time.
Well, it wasn't very St. Luke's Hospital.
It was pretty well looked after.
It did look like one, yes.
And I saw a Good Peace store.
My goodness, we used to get Good Peace catalogues,
you know, of course.
The mail order house, something like that.
So it took in a whole huge block running there.
And as you said, you know, everybody spoke English.
I thought I had to speak French.
I said, no, they all spoke English.
But you say that's not right.
Thank you.
I wonder why a little bird like that
takes his water from you.
I have put water cans out on the fence.
I don't know what you're talking about.
No?
Maybe early in the morning.
The dew.
Maybe.
I don't know if the voice is in the background.
I might add a little history to this tape.
On March the 31st, we sold the property,
the building, and the company shares
to Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan,
who will use it as a vehicle
to privatize.
This may surprise a lot of people.
Why?
Why they bought the company.
But they had to have a company
that was legal for life,
and ours had to meet all the requirements.
I just thought somebody might be interested
in this information.
Thank you.
This is July the 1st, 1989.
Beautiful day.
I'm up by myself at 9 o'clock.
Pete and I.
And I've been going over the tapes
I received from Andy Hemmer.
And I happened to run across this one.
So I wanted to hear Sister Hillary sing that song again.
I just run it over.
So I'll close off for now.
Over and out, they say.
